Triggering Event: Every morning, she'd walk past his empty chair at the kitchen table, a bitter taste rising in her throat like yesterday's coffee. Today, she noticed a crack in the seat he used to occupy, a subtle fault line mirroring her own heart. She picked up his favorite mug from the draining board, now hers alone to use and wash. The bitterness welled up as she felt the coldness of the unused chair, its emptiness echoing the hollowness within her.

What the fuck if I start sweating buckets because it's too hot?! Ugh, why did he have to leave me with this fucked-up chair?! It must be cursed! What if it makes me break out in hives?! What if it makes me feel like shit?! What if I get sick?! What if I die?! What if I can't even sit here anymore?! What the fuck is wrong with me?! Why does it always happen to me?! Why does everything go wrong when I try to move on?! What if I never find love again?! What if I end up alone forever?! What if no one ever wants me?! What if I'm just not good enough?! Fuck! What if my heart stops beating right here and now?! What if I suffocate while trying to hold back tears?! What if I cry so hard that I pass out?! Fuck! What if I can't even breathe?! What if my body gives out?! What if I collapse right here?! Fuck! What if I don't wake up tomorrow?! What if I'm stuck here forever?! What if I lose all hope?! What if... what if... WHAT IF...!!!

Triggering Event: She found an old photograph tucked into her cluttered desk drawer at work. It was of her and her ex, laughing together in their favorite park. She hadn't seen it since they'd parted ways six months ago. A lump formed in her throat as she traced his face with her fingertip. The bell above the store's entrance chimed, startling her back to reality. Another customer had entered, but all she could focus on was the hollow ache in her chest that felt heavier than any bag of clothes or shoes she'd ever carried.

Triggering Event: At the monthly school board meeting, she presents her proposal for a new educational program, but it's quickly dismissed by the board members with barely a glance at her notes. Triggering Event: At 6 PM, he locked up the store alone as usual, the harsh fluorescent lights flickering off with a hum. Walking home under the bare winter trees, his reflection in the deserted shop windows showed only a gaunt old man. The holiday decorations seemed mocking, their cheer hollow and distant. His phone stayed silent, no messages from the kids or his estranged daughter. He paused by the park bench where they used to picnic as a family, now just another empty space under the cold moon.

Triggering Event: An hour before closing, she noticed a young man lingering near the perfume counter, his eyes darting around nervously. She'd seen him before, always at this time of day. Today, he reached out to touch a bottle, then quickly pulled his hand back as if burned. Her heart began to race; she couldn't shake the feeling that something was off. As he approached her with a polite smile, she felt her anxiety spike, wondering what he might ask for this time.
Generated Assessment: What is wrong with me? I feel like I'm losing my mind. Every little thing sets off some irrational fear inside me. The way people look at me, the things they say, every glance feels like a warning sign. I know it's stupid, but I can't help how I feel. Even when I try to talk to others, my mind starts racing with worst-case scenarios. It’s exhausting. I feel like I’m just waiting for something terrible to happen, even though I know deep down I have nothing to worry about. I hate these thoughts, but they keep coming back. I wish I could just let go of all this anxiety, but it seems like it’s always there. I don’t want to be like this anymore, but I don’t know how to stop it.

Triggering Event: The daily mail arrives at his doorstep, untouched by anyone but the postman. He notices a glossy catalog among the usual suspects - bills and flyers. It's from their favorite furniture store, where they'd spent hours together, planning, dreaming. His late wife's handwriting is still visible on the envelope, "For our new home," she'd written, years ago. He leaves it unopened, letting the wind blow it off the porch, untended and forgotten.

Triggering Event: She woke up to find his side of the bed untouched, the cold sheets still neatly tucked in. The house was quiet, save for the soft ticking of the grandfather clock he'd bought at their last antique market outing. In the kitchen, the coffee maker hummed quietly, but there were no two mugs waiting on the counter this morning, no note with his messy scrawl reminding her to check the fridge for his latest experiment in pickling. She stood alone in the empty room, the weight of neglect settling heavy around her shoulders like an old, familiar cloak.
Generated Assessment: "Wow. I'm so glad she's here. It looks like everything is perfect. Just as it should be. I mean, who wouldn't want to live in such a beautiful home? The whole place smells just right, a little bit of him still lingering in every corner. And that smell... Oh, that smell is so nice. Reminds me of all those times we spent together, just us two, getting lost in the moment. Yeah, I really miss him. He was always making me laugh, even when he didn't mean to. But now... Well, I guess I'll just have to find someone else to fill the void. Someone who can appreciate the beauty of our life together."
